clusters.title: Trump to address Davos as allies push back against his bid for Greenland
clusters.neutral_headline: US allies unite against Trump’s threats to take over Greenland at Davos

items.title: Trump to address Davos as allies push back against his bid for Greenland
items.standfirst: President Trump will address the gathering of world leaders, CEOs and policymakers as America's allies balk at his efforts to acquire Greenland.
items.content: President Trump will address the gathering of world leaders, CEOs and policymakers as America's allies balk at his efforts to acquire Greenland.

items.title: Trump to speak at Davos as his Greenland push, tariff threats take center stage
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump is set Wednesday to speak at the World Economic Forum, directly addressing an audience that has been put on edge by his intensifying aggression toward the allied territory of Greenland. Trump's speech is scheduled to begin at 8:30 a.m. ET. The address will be bookended by…
items.content: President Donald Trump is set Wednesday to speak at the World Economic Forum, directly addressing an audience that has been put on edge by his intensifying aggression toward the allied territory of Greenland. Trump's speech is scheduled to begin at 8:30 a.m. ET. The address will be bookended by…

items.title: Trump heads for frosty welcome in Davos amid tension with European allies
items.standfirst: The US President Donald Trump is on his way to the Davos World Economic Forum. He is not expecting a warm reception from many of his European allies who are in attendance, who are opposing his attempts to take over Greenland. The day before, French President Emmanuel Macron answered his tariff threats saying he preferred "respect to bullies", and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney sided with European members of NATO, saying Canada was committed to the alliance's article 5.
items.content: The US President Donald Trump is on his way to the Davos World Economic Forum. He is not expecting a warm reception from many of his European allies who are in attendance, who are opposing his attempts to take over Greenland. The day before, French President Emmanuel Macron answered his tariff threats saying he preferred "respect to bullies", and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney sided with European members of NATO, saying Canada was committed to the alliance's article 5.

items.title: US allies unite against Trump’s threats to take over Greenland at Davos
items.standfirst: US allies reacted to President Donald Trump’s threats to take over Greenland on Tuesday.
items.content: US allies reacted to President Donald Trump’s threats to take over Greenland on Tuesday.

items.title: In ritzy Davos, Trump to meet with world leaders he's pressured over Greenland
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump arrives at Davos in Switzerland with Europe on edge and the NATO alliance in crisis over his push to wrest control of Greenland.
items.content: President Donald Trump arrives at Davos in Switzerland with Europe on edge and the NATO alliance in crisis over his push to wrest control of Greenland.

items.title: Trump heads to Davos after upending European relations over Greenland
items.standfirst: The U.S. president is set to meet with an array of leaders to discuss Greenland. Trump's push to acquire Greenland has turned to antagonism toward allies in recent days.
items.content: The U.S. president is set to meet with an array of leaders to discuss Greenland. Trump's push to acquire Greenland has turned to antagonism toward allies in recent days.(Image credit: Fabrice Coffrini)

items.title: Live: France calls for NATO exercise in Greenland
items.standfirst: France has called for a NATO exercise to be held in Greenland, the French presidential office said on Wednesday. The proposal comes as world leaders gather at the World Economic Meeting in Davos, where US President Donald Trump is expected to continue to push for his “need” to take control of the autonomous Danish territory. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.
items.content: France has called for a NATO exercise to be held in Greenland, the French presidential office said on Wednesday. The proposal comes as world leaders gather at the World Economic Meeting in Davos, where US President Donald Trump is expected to continue to push for his “need” to take control of the autonomous Danish territory. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

items.title: Trump's full messages with European leaders – and what they tell us
items.standfirst: Experts tell BBC what to read into private messages between US President Donald Trump and European leaders that have been shared publicly .
items.content: Experts tell BBC what to read into private messages between US President Donald Trump and European leaders that have been shared publicly .

items.title: Trump shares texts from leaders and vows 'no going back' on Greenland
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump shared a private message from France's Emmanuel Macron, part of a flurry of activity as he added new fuel to his clash with Europe over the Arctic territory.
items.content: President Donald Trump shared a private message from France's Emmanuel Macron, part of a flurry of activity as he added new fuel to his clash with Europe over the Arctic territory.

items.title: Former South Korean PM jailed for 23 years for role in martial law insurrection
items.standfirst: Han Duck-soo verdict marks first judicial ruling stemming from ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol’s 2024 martial law decreeSouth Korea’s former prime minister Han Duck-soo has been sentenced to 23 years in prison for his role in an insurrection stemming from the former president Yoon Suk Yeol’s failed martial law declaration.The judge, Lee Jin-kwan, ordered Han’s immediate detention. Continue reading...

items.title: Life sentence for man who killed Japan's ex-PM Shinzo Abe
items.standfirst: Abe's assassination stunned the country where there is virtually no gun crime.
items.content: Abe's assassination stunned the country where there is virtually no gun crime.

items.title: Gunman jailed for life in killing of Japan ex-PM Shinzo Abe
items.standfirst: The gunman charged with killing Japan's former prime minister Shinzo Abe was found guilty January 21 and jailed for life. The shooting more than three years ago forced a reckoning in a country with little experience of gun violence, and ignited scrutiny of alleged ties between prominent conservative lawmakers and a secretive sect, the Unification Church.
items.content: The gunman charged with killing Japan's former prime minister Shinzo Abe was found guilty January 21 and jailed for life. The shooting more than three years ago forced a reckoning in a country with little experience of gun violence, and ignited scrutiny of alleged ties between prominent conservative lawmakers and a secretive sect, the Unification Church.

items.title: South Korea's former prime minister jailed over martial law declaration
items.standfirst: South Korea's former prime minister has been sentenced to 23 years in prison on charges relating to the failed martial law declaration in 2024.
items.content: South Korea's former prime minister has been sentenced to 23 years in prison on charges relating to the failed martial law declaration in 2024.

items.title: S Korea’s former PM found guilty of insurrection, given 23 years in prison
items.standfirst: Ex-Prime Minister Han Duck-soo accused of failing to hold a lawful cabinet meeting following martial law declaration.
items.content: Ex-Prime Minister Han Duck-soo accused of failing to hold a lawful cabinet meeting following martial law declaration.

items.title: Man who killed former Japanese PM Shinzo Abe jailed for life
items.standfirst: A man has been sentenced to life in prison for assassinating former Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe, according to public broadcaster NHK.
items.content: A man has been sentenced to life in prison for assassinating former Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe, according to public broadcaster NHK.

items.title: Man who assassinated former Japanese leader Abe is sentenced to life in prison
items.standfirst: A Japanese court on Wednesday sentenced a 45-year-old man to life imprisonment for fatally shooting former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, public broadcaster NHK reported, in an incident that stunned the nation three and a half years ago.
items.content: A Japanese court on Wednesday sentenced a 45-year-old man to life imprisonment for fatally shooting former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, public broadcaster NHK reported, in an incident that stunned the nation three and a half years ago.

items.title: Ex-Japanese Prime Minister Abe’s killer sentenced to life
items.standfirst: Tetsuya Yamagami shot the Japanese politician dead in 2022.
items.content: Tetsuya Yamagami shot the Japanese politician dead in 2022.

items.title: Japan jails ex-PM Shinzo Abe assassin for life after guilty verdict in 2022 killing
items.standfirst: The gunman charged with killing Japan’s former prime minister Shinzo Abe was found guilty and sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday, more than three years after the brazen daylight assassination shocked the country. Judge Shinichi Tanaka handed down the ruling at a court in the city of Nara.
items.content: The gunman charged with killing Japan’s former prime minister Shinzo Abe was found guilty and sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday, more than three years after the brazen daylight assassination shocked the country. Judge Shinichi Tanaka handed down the ruling at a court in the city of Nara.

clusters.title: Syria: Did Washington "abandon" the Kurds?
clusters.neutral_headline: Syrian army reportedly enters detention camp holding relatives of IS suspects

items.title: Syria: Did Washington "abandon" the Kurds?
items.standfirst: Syria's government and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces agreed a new ceasefire on January 20 as Washington said the SDF's purpose in fighting Islamic State group jihadists was largely over. The announcement came after the army sent reinforcements to the Kurds' province stronghold in the northeast. FRANCE 24's Wassim Nasr breaks it down for us.
items.content: Syria's government and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces agreed a new ceasefire on January 20 as Washington said the SDF's purpose in fighting Islamic State group jihadists was largely over. The announcement came after the army sent reinforcements to the Kurds' province stronghold in the northeast. FRANCE 24's Wassim Nasr breaks it down for us.

items.title: Syrian government forces advance in previously Kurd-held territory
items.standfirst: Syrian government forces are continuing their advance in the country's northeast to take back territory previously held by the Kurds. Meanwhile, the interior ministry says some 80 Islamic State group members have been recaptured after 120 escaped from a prison on January 19 amid clashes between government forces and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces. The fighting comes despite a ceasefire signed between the two sides on January 18.
items.content: Syrian government forces are continuing their advance in the country's northeast to take back territory previously held by the Kurds. Meanwhile, the interior ministry says some 80 Islamic State group members have been recaptured after 120 escaped from a prison on January 19 amid clashes between government forces and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces. The fighting comes despite a ceasefire signed between the two sides on January 18.

items.title: Syrian army reportedly enters detention camp holding relatives of IS suspects
items.standfirst: Apparent move follows withdrawal of Kurdish forces from al-Hawl, where about 24,000 people are detainedSyria’s army has reportedly entered the country’s vast al-Hawl detention camp that houses relatives of suspected Islamic State jihadists, after Kurdish forces withdrew.A large group of soldiers opened the camp’s metal gate and entered while others guarded the entrance, according to an Agence France-Presse journalist at the scene. Continue reading...
items.content: Apparent move follows withdrawal of Kurdish forces from al-Hawl, where about 24,000 people are detainedSyria’s army has reportedly entered the country’s vast al-Hawl detention camp that houses relatives of suspected Islamic State jihadists, after Kurdish forces withdrew.A large group of soldiers opened the camp’s metal gate and entered while others guarded the entrance, according to an Agence France-Presse journalist at the scene. Continue reading...

items.title: Syrian army takes control of Al-Hol camp housing IS group families
items.standfirst: The Syrian army on Wednesday entered the Al-Hol dentention camp in northeastern Syria, which houses families of suspected Islamic State (IS) group fighters. The camp was previously guarded by Kurdish forces, who withdrew to defend other cities prior to a ceasefire deal with the Syrian army.
items.content: The Syrian army on Wednesday entered the Al-Hol dentention camp in northeastern Syria, which houses families of suspected Islamic State (IS) group fighters. The camp was previously guarded by Kurdish forces, who withdrew to defend other cities prior to a ceasefire deal with the Syrian army.

items.standfirst: The Syrian government has announced a four-day ceasefire with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces.
items.content: The Syrian government has announced a four-day ceasefire with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces.

items.title: New ceasefire in Syria after Kurdish-led forces pull out of camp for IS families
items.standfirst: The government announces a four-day ceasefire with the SDF, which says it was "compelled" to withdraw its fighters from al-Hol camp.
items.content: The government announces a four-day ceasefire with the SDF, which says it was "compelled" to withdraw its fighters from al-Hol camp.

items.title: Kurdish forces withdraw from IS detention camp in north-east Syria
items.standfirst: US says it no longer supports SDF, which left camp as it loses swathes of territory to government forcesKurdish-led forces in Syria have announced a withdrawal from a detention camp in north-east Syria housing tens of thousands of Islamic State-linked detainees, as the US declared it was no longer supporting them.The fate of al-Hawl, which houses among others the most radical foreign women suspected to have been members of IS and their families, is of great concern to neighbouring states and the international community. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Investigation in Spanish train collision "could take months"
clusters.neutral_headline: Train driver killed in second deadly Spain rail crash in days

items.title: Investigation in Spanish train collision "could take months"
items.standfirst: A high-speed train in southern Spain derailed on January 18, colliding with another high-speed train, killing at least 42 people and injuring more than 150, Spanish authorities reported. Two days later, another train crashed into a wall which had fell onto the train tracks. Despite safety concerns regarding the railway system, authorities say investigation into the first incident could take months. FRANCE 24's Sarah Morris has more from Madrid.
items.content: A high-speed train in southern Spain derailed on January 18, colliding with another high-speed train, killing at least 42 people and injuring more than 150, Spanish authorities reported. Two days later, another train crashed into a wall which had fell onto the train tracks. Despite safety concerns regarding the railway system, authorities say investigation into the first incident could take months. FRANCE 24's Sarah Morris has more from Madrid.

items.title: Safety concerns grow as second deadly train crash occurs in Spain
items.standfirst: A commuter train near Barcelona ploughed into the rubble of a collapsed wall on January 20, killing one and injuring dozens. The latest incident is likely to raise more questions about Spanish transport safety, coming two days after the collision of two high-speed trains in the southern region of Andalusia killed 42 people -- the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.
items.content: A commuter train near Barcelona ploughed into the rubble of a collapsed wall on January 20, killing one and injuring dozens. The latest incident is likely to raise more questions about Spanish transport safety, coming two days after the collision of two high-speed trains in the southern region of Andalusia killed 42 people -- the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.

items.content: At least 37 people have been injured, five seriously, in a second crash, after Sunday's two-train collision in Andalusia.

items.title: Supreme court to consider Trump’s bid to fire Lisa Cook from Fed board – US politics live
items.standfirst: A federal court blocked Cook’s removal, and she remains on the Fed’s rate-setting boardGraeme Wearden tracks the latest world business, economic and financial news in our daily liveblogDonald Trump’s treasury secretary has dismissed Denmark as “irrelevant” in his administration’s latest attack on a traditional US ally, as world leaders in Davos prepare for the president’s arrival in the Swiss ski resort.The size of Denmark’s investment in US Treasury bonds, like Denmark itself, is irrelevant.It is less than $100m[£75m]. They’ve been selling treasuries for years. I’m not concerned at all. Continue reading...
items.content: A federal court blocked Cook’s removal, and she remains on the Fed’s rate-setting boardGraeme Wearden tracks the latest world business, economic and financial news in our daily liveblogDonald Trump’s treasury secretary has dismissed Denmark as “irrelevant” in his administration’s latest attack on a traditional US ally, as world leaders in Davos prepare for the president’s arrival in the Swiss ski resort.The size of Denmark’s investment in US Treasury bonds, like Denmark itself, is irrelevant.It is less than $100m[£75m]. They’ve been selling treasuries for years. I’m not concerned at all. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Netanyahu to join Trump ‘board of peace’ despite previous objections
clusters.neutral_headline: Netanyahu to join Trump ‘board of peace’ despite previous objections

items.title: Netanyahu to join Trump ‘board of peace’ despite previous objections
items.standfirst: Israeli prime minister accepts position on US-proposed body with initial remit to oversee Gaza ceasefireIsrael’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said on Wednesday that he had agreed to join a US-backed “board of peace” proposed by Donald Trump, despite his office having earlier criticised the composition of its executive committee.The body, chaired by the US president, was initially presented as a limited forum of world leaders tasked with overseeing a ceasefire in Gaza. More recently, however, the initiative appears to have expanded well beyond that remit, with the Trump camp extending invitations to dozens of countries and suggesting the board could evolve into a vehicle for brokering conflicts far beyond the Middle East. Continue reading...
items.content: Israeli prime minister accepts position on US-proposed body with initial remit to oversee Gaza ceasefireIsrael’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said on Wednesday that he had agreed to join a US-backed “board of peace” proposed by Donald Trump, despite his office having earlier criticised the composition of its executive committee.The body, chaired by the US president, was initially presented as a limited forum of world leaders tasked with overseeing a ceasefire in Gaza. More recently, however, the initiative appears to have expanded well beyond that remit, with the Trump camp extending invitations to dozens of countries and suggesting the board could evolve into a vehicle for brokering conflicts far beyond the Middle East. Continue reading...

items.title: Toby Carvery owner faces eviction from north London site for felling ancient oak
items.standfirst: Felling of 500-year-old oak has provoked fury from public and Enfield council, which leases land to Mitchells & ButlersThe restaurant chain Toby Carvery is facing eviction from one of its sites after taking a chainsaw to an ancient oak tree without the permission of its council landlord.The partial felling last April of the 500-year-old oak on the edge of a Toby Carvery car park in Whitewebbs Park, Enfield, provoked widespread public dismay and fury from Enfield council, which leases the land to the restaurant’s owners Mitchells & Butlers Retail (M&B). Continue reading...
items.content: Felling of 500-year-old oak has provoked fury from public and Enfield council, which leases land to Mitchells & ButlersThe restaurant chain Toby Carvery is facing eviction from one of its sites after taking a chainsaw to an ancient oak tree without the permission of its council landlord.The partial felling last April of the 500-year-old oak on the edge of a Toby Carvery car park in Whitewebbs Park, Enfield, provoked widespread public dismay and fury from Enfield council, which leases the land to the restaurant’s owners Mitchells & Butlers Retail (M&B). Continue reading...

items.title: Driving test cheating up 47% in Great Britain, prompting road safety concerns
items.standfirst: DVSA says increase to 2,844 recorded cases in year to end of September is down to more cheating and better detectionAttempts to cheat on driving tests in England, Scotland and Wales increased by 47% in a year, figures show, raising concerns about road safety.There were 2,844 cases recorded in the year to the end of September 2025, according to figures by the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency (DVSA), up from 1,940 during the previous 12 months, and 1,274 in 2018-19. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Trump administration claims offshore wind poses a threat. But it won't say how. Late last month, the Trump administration halted construction on billions of dollars worth of offshore wind projects after the Defense Department allegedly raised new national security concerns about the facilities.…
items.content: Trump administration claims offshore wind poses a threat. But it won't say how. Late last month, the Trump administration halted construction on billions of dollars worth of offshore wind projects after the Defense Department allegedly raised new national security concerns about the facilities.…

items.title: Trump administration claims offshore wind poses a threat. But it won't say how.
items.standfirst: The Interior Department said pausing construction of offshore wind farms would allow the government agencies to work with project developers to mitigate potential risks. But wind companies say the administration isn't sharing information about newly-discovered threats.
items.content: The Interior Department said pausing construction of offshore wind farms would allow the government agencies to work with project developers to mitigate potential risks. But wind companies say the administration isn't sharing information about newly-discovered threats.(Image credit: Michael Dwyer/AP)

items.title: Trump officials defend effort to acquire Greenland as matter of national security
items.standfirst: President Trump is heading to Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday night, where he will continue his insistence that the U.S. take control of Greenland. CBS News senior White House and political correspondent Ed O'Keefe spoke with two White House officials at the World Economic Forum to learn more about the administration's stance.
items.content: President Trump is heading to Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday night, where he will continue his insistence that the U.S. take control of Greenland. CBS News senior White House and political correspondent Ed O'Keefe spoke with two White House officials at the World Economic Forum to learn more about the administration's stance.

items.standfirst: The US president says it is "another in a very long line of National Security reasons why Greenland has to be acquired".

clusters.title: Colombia sentences ex-paramilitary leader Mancuso to 40 years in jail
clusters.neutral_headline: Colombia sentences ex-paramilitary leader Mancuso to 40 years in jail

items.title: Colombia sentences ex-paramilitary leader Mancuso to 40 years in jail
items.standfirst: Salvatore Mancuso's group committed more than 100 crimes, many targeting an indigenous group, the tribunal ruled.
items.content: Salvatore Mancuso's group committed more than 100 crimes, many targeting an indigenous group, the tribunal ruled.

items.title: Colombian ex-paramilitary leader jailed for crimes against Indigenous groups
items.standfirst: Salvatore Mancuso given 40-year sentence, which could be reduced after truth and reparation activitiesA Colombian court has sentenced a former paramilitary leader to 40 years in prison for crimes committed against Indigenous communities in the province of La Guajira, including homicides, forced disappearances and the displacement of people from 2002 to 2006.The special tribunal that hears cases from the country’s armed conflict said in its ruling that Salvatore Mancuso was responsible for 117 crimes committed by fighters under his command in La Guajira. However, it added that Mancuso’s time in prison could be reduced to eight years, if he collaborated with truth and reparation activities that benefited victims of his former paramilitary group. Continue reading...
items.content: Salvatore Mancuso given 40-year sentence, which could be reduced after truth and reparation activitiesA Colombian court has sentenced a former paramilitary leader to 40 years in prison for crimes committed against Indigenous communities in the province of La Guajira, including homicides, forced disappearances and the displacement of people from 2002 to 2006.The special tribunal that hears cases from the country’s armed conflict said in its ruling that Salvatore Mancuso was responsible for 117 crimes committed by fighters under his command in La Guajira. However, it added that Mancuso’s time in prison could be reduced to eight years, if he collaborated with truth and reparation activities that benefited victims of his former paramilitary group. Continue reading...
